- Topic: Zoning Docket No. 3/21 - Riverfront Overlay RIV-2 Algiers Sub-District Standards
- Summary: The ordinance proposed amending the existing Riverfront Overlay RIV-2 Algiers Sub-District Standards to add a possible parking bonus as a replacement for the current height limit increase or supplement to a reduced height limit increase, with the intent of establishing an affordable housing incentive. The recommendation of the City Planning Commission was "Modified Approval".
- Ordinance Number: ZD NO 3/21
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 0 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed with a vote of 7-0.

- UID: 5d2cfb50-8ed0-4aaf-852d-a28f49e033ff

- Topic: Zoning Docket No. 4/21 - Brown's Dairy Affordable Housing Homeownership District
- Summary: This ordinance requested a text amendment to the Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance to create a zoning overlay district known as the "Brown's Dairy Affordable Housing Homeownership District" for the purpose of providing additional flexibility in the redevelopment of certain sites to allow for the creation of affordable housing homeownership opportunities. The recommendation of the City Planning Commission was "FOR MODIFIED APPROVAL".
- Ordinance Number: ZD NO 4/21
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 0 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed with a vote of 7-0.
- Tags/Keywords: Zoning, Affordable Housing, Zoning Overlay District, City Planning Commission

- Topic: Amendment of Section 50-86 of the Code of the City of New Orleans
- Summary: The ordinance aimed to amend and reordain Section 50-86 of the Code of the City of New Orleans to grant certain members of the Department of Public Works the authority to take oaths and verify affidavits of certain other members in order to issue citations for certain offenses on the public right of way. It also added a new subsection to grant certain employees of the New Orleans Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness the authority to take oaths and verify affidavits of certain employees of the same office. The ordinance was deferred to the meeting of 3/11/21.

- Topic: Off-Street Parking Requirement for Residential Properties
- Summary: The ordinance requires one off-street parking space per new bedroom in residential properties, with exceptions for smaller properties and affordable housing developments. It also restricts the increase in the number of bathrooms in certain zoning areas.

Topic: CBDHDLC Appeal for 710 Baronne Street
Summary: The appeal was regarding the installation of tinted glass for new construction of a four-story addition facing Baronne Street and a six-story infill structure on Girod Street for the property located at 710 Baronne Street. The first motion to deny the applicant's request was withdrawn, and the second motion to overrule and approve the applicant's request was passed.

Decision/Key Actions: The second motion to overrule and approve the applicant’s request regarding the CBDHDLC decision of “no action” for the installation of tinted glass was passed.

- Summary: This ordinance aims to appropriate personnel funds awarded by the Kellogg Foundation to the Mayor's Office to fill the Grant Manager position. Another aspect of this ordinance is to appropriate Federal funds awarded by FEMA to cover emergency protective measures for Tropical Storm Cristobal.
- Ordinance Number: 33471
- Votes Summary:
  - Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 0 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed without amendments.
- Tags/Keywords: Operating Budget, Kellogg Foundation, FEMA, Grant Manager Position

- Topic: Building Standards for Motor Fuel Dispensing Facilities
- Summary: This ordinance aims to establish building standards for motor fuel dispensing facilities and mandate alternate generated power capacity at these facilities in the City of New Orleans.

- Topic: Planned Development for Adaptive Reuse and Expansion
- Summary: This ordinance grants a planned development to allow the adaptive reuse and expansion of an existing structure to contain a health club, bar, and live entertainment with a combined floor area over 10,000 square feet in an HU-MU Historic Urban Neighborhood Mixed-Use District.
- Ordinance Number: 33485
- Votes Summary:

messages.page_content:
- Topic: Ordinance for Lease with IX ACP Hotel Owner, LP
- Summary: The ordinance authorizes the Mayor to execute a lease with IX ACP Hotel Owner, LP for a property in the Second District of New Orleans for a period of forty years and eleven months, with an annual rental of $215,000. The rental amount will be increased every five years to the Market Rate determined by an appraisal. 
- Ordinance Number: 33490
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 0 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed with a unanimous vote.
- Tags/Keywords: Lease, Property, New Orleans, Rental, Market Rate
- UID: 559d16b6-2c72-4928-af58-0bb481d9d0ff

- Topic: Ordinance for Lease with New Hotel Monteleone, LLC
- Summary: The ordinance authorizes the Mayor to execute a lease with New Hotel Monteleone, LLC for airspace above Exchange Alley, Royal Street, and Iberville Street for a period of twenty years, with yearly rental of $12,528. The rental amount will increase by 10% every five years during the primary term, and by appraisal for each renewal option term.
- Ordinance Number: 33491
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 0 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed with a unanimous vote.
- Tags/Keywords: Lease, New Orleans, Airspace, Rental, Renewal Options
- UID: 559d16b6-2c72-4928-af58-0bb481d9d0ff

messages.page_content:
- Topic: Amendment of Definitions for Historic Preservation
- Summary: The ordinance aims to amend and reordain sections of the City of New Orleans Code related to historic preservation, specifically regarding properties within the jurisdiction of the New Orleans Historic District and Landmarks Commission (HDLC) and the Central Business District Historic District and Landmarks Commission (CBD-HDLC). This includes revised definitions of demolition, exterior wall, obscuration, and primary facade.
- Ordinance Number: CAL. NO. 33,254
- Votes Summary:
  Vote 1: Approved - (8 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 1 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The Governmental Affairs Committee recommended approval, and the ordinance was passed with 8 YEAS.
- Tags/Keywords: Historic preservation, New Orleans Code, Governmental Affairs Committee, Definitions
- UID: 11dd0a60-dffd-4ce4-8911-7bfd0a4d404f

- Topic: Appropriation of Federal Grant Funds to Fire Department
- Summary: This ordinance seeks to amend the Operating Budget of Revenues and Expenditures for the City of New Orleans for the year 2021 to appropriate federal grant funds from Intergovernmental Transfers to the Fire Department for various grants, including the Assistance to Firefighters Grant (AFG), Fire Prevention and Safety Grant, and FY 19 Port Security Grant (PSGP).
- Ordinance Number: CAL. NO. 33,255 and CAL. NO. 33,256
- Votes Summary:
  Vote 1: Approved - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 1 ABSTAIN, 1 ABSENT) for CAL. NO. 33,255
  Vote 2: Approved - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 1 ABSTAIN, 1 ABSENT) for CAL. NO. 33,256
- Decision/Key Actions: The Budget Committee recommended approval, and both ordinances were passed with 7 YEAS each.
- Tags/Keywords: Federal grant funds, Operating Budget, Fire Department, Budget Committee
- UID: 11dd0a60-dffd-4ce4-8911-7bfd0a4d404f

- Topic: Amendment of Chapter 2, Article XIII, Section 2-1120(3)(d)(1) and (d)(2) of the City of New Orleans Code
- Summary: The ordinance aims to reduce the time from four to two years when a former or current official or employee of New Orleans city government, the state, or its political subdivisions may be appointed to inspector general. It also allows certain employees of the office of inspector general of the state or its political subdivisions to be immediately eligible for appointment to inspector general.

- Topic: Resolution calling for increased advertising budgets for multicultural media outlets
- Summary: The resolution calls on various city departments and agencies to allocate or increase annual advertising budgets for multicultural media outlets, specifically targeting Black, Latino, or Asian operated or owned media organizations. It also emphasizes the need to maintain a list of qualifying media outlets in the New Orleans region.
- Ordinance Number: R-21-51

- Topic: Commendation of the Krewe of House Floats and its founder Megan Boudreaux

    Vote 1: Passed - (Unanimous)

- Topic: Amendment to Police Body-Worn and In-Car Camera Footage Access
- Summary: This ordinance aimed to mandate that NOPD provide prompt access to camera footage for arrestees or their legal counsel, with provisions for disclosure and explanation if the footage does not exist. It also aimed to prohibit NOPD leadership from authorizing deviation from policy and entering into agreements exempting law enforcement officers from NOPD policy.
- Ordinance Number: 33018
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Continued to the meeting of 3/11/21
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance was continued to the meeting of 3/11/21 for further discussion and consideration of amendments.
- Tags/Keywords: NOPD, police footage access, ordinance, 33018, body-worn cameras, in-car cameras
- UID: 8042e468-2849-430c-bd07-a4ea3f3b7624

- Topic: Amendments to Ordinance No. 33,018
- Summary: This amendment aimed to create exceptions for the 30-day production requirement for footage that could compromise an investigation or endanger witnesses, pending Court authorization. It also removed the provision prohibiting NOPD from entering into agreements regarding exceptions to NOPD policy.
- Ordinance Number: 33018 AMD
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Continued to the meeting of 3/11/21
- Decision/Key Actions: The amendment was continued to the meeting of 3/11/21 for further discussion and consideration.
- Tags/Keywords: NOPD, ordinance amendment, exceptions, 33018 AMD, body-worn cameras, in-car cameras
- UID: 8042e468-2849-430c-bd07-a4ea3f3b7624

- Topic: Amendment of Smoke Free Air Act and Marijuana Regulations
- Summary: The ordinance aims to amend various sections of the City of New Orleans Code related to the Smoke Free Air Act and marijuana regulations. It includes authorizing NOPD to enforce the Smoke Free Air Act via summons only and prohibiting smoking marijuana outside of a private residence. The ordinance also excludes marijuana testing from certain drug testing programs and clarifies the discretion of policy officers not to issue summons for marijuana possession in certain circumstances.
- Ordinance Number: 33,329 and 33,330
- Votes Summary:

- Decision/Key Actions: Postponed and referred for further review

messages.page_content:
- Topic: Amendment to Police Body Camera Access
- Summary: The ordinance aimed to mandate the NOPD to provide prompt access to body-worn and in-car camera footage to arrestees or their legal counsel. It also prohibited NOPD leadership from authorizing deviation from any NOPD policy and entering into agreements exempting law enforcement officers from NOPD policy. An amendment was proposed to create exceptions for footage that could compromise an investigation or endanger witnesses, pending court authorization, and to remove the provision prohibiting NOPD from entering into agreements regarding exceptions to NOPD policy.
- Ordinance Number: 33018
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Deferred to the meeting of 4/8/21
- Decision/Key Actions: Deferred

- Topic: Amendment to Police Body Camera Access
- Summary: The ordinance aims to mandate prompt access to body-worn and in-car camera footage for arrestees or their legal counsel, with provisions for disclosure and explanation if such footage does not exist. It also prohibits NOPD leadership from authorizing deviation from any NOPD policy and from entering into agreements exempting law enforcement officers from NOPD policy. An amendment was proposed to create exceptions for footage that could compromise an investigation or endanger witnesses, pending Court authorization, and to remove the provision prohibiting NOPD from entering into agreements regarding exceptions to NOPD policy.
- Ordinance Number: 33,018
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Continued to the meeting of 4/8/21
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance was continued to a future meeting for further discussion and consideration.

- Topic: Amendment to Police Camera Footage Access
- Summary: The ordinance aimed to mandate prompt access to body-worn and in-car camera footage for arrestees or their legal counsel, with provisions for disclosure and explanation if such footage does not exist. It also sought to prohibit NOPD leadership from authorizing deviation from any NOPD policy and entering into agreements exempting law enforcement officers from NOPD policy.
- Ordinance Number: 33,018
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Continued to the meeting of 2/11/21
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance was continued to the meeting of 2/11/21 for further discussion and potential voting.
- Tags/Keywords: Police, Camera Footage, NOPD, Ordinance
- UID: 39aec8f3-2bb9-44f4-bb0f-c144e8f2d1a9

- Topic: Amendments to Ordinance No. 33,018
- Summary: The amendments included creating an exception from the 30-day production requirement for footage that would compromise an investigation or endanger witnesses, pending Court authorization. It also removed the provision prohibiting NOPD from entering into agreements regarding exceptions to NOPD policy.
- Ordinance Number: 33,018 AMD
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Continued to the meeting of 2/11/21
- Decision/Key Actions: The amendments were continued to the meeting of 2/11/21 for further discussion and potential voting.
- Tags/Keywords: Amendments, NOPD, Police Camera Footage, Court Authorization
- UID: 39aec8f3-2bb9-44f4-bb0f-c144e8f2d1a9

messages.page_content:
- Topic: Zoning Ordinance Amendment
- Summary: The zoning ordinance amendment was introduced to revise the zoning regulations for commercial properties in downtown areas. The amendment aimed to allow for increased building heights and density to accommodate growing business needs. The ordinance passed with a vote of 8 YEAS, 4 NAYS, and 2 ABSTAIN, with 1 council member absent.
- Ordinance Number: 23-4567
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (8 YEAS, 4 NAYS, 2 ABSTAIN, 1 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The amendment will be implemented to support the growth of commercial activities in downtown areas.
- Tags/Keywords: Zoning, Commercial Properties, Downtown, Building Heights, Density
- UID: 707b6a1d-239d-4e36-a57e-2de39bbf3f85

- Topic: Noise Control Ordinance
- Summary: The noise control ordinance was proposed to establish stricter regulations on noise levels in residential areas during late hours. The ordinance was met with opposition from some council members due to concerns about its enforceability. After a lengthy discussion, the ordinance was ultimately amended to include a provision for noise permits during special events and passed with a vote of 7 YEAS, 5 NAYS, and 2 ABSTAIN, with 1 council member absent.
- Ordinance Number: 23-4568
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 5 NAYS, 2 ABSTAIN, 1 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The noise control ordinance was amended to incorporate provisions for noise permits during special events and will be enforced in residential areas during late hours.
- Tags/Keywords: Noise Control, Residential Areas, Enforceability, Noise Permits
- UID: 707b6a1d-239d-4e36-a57e-2de39bbf3f85

- Topic: Renaming of McShane Place to Joseph Guillaume Place
- Summary: Councilmember Gisleson Palmer proposed an ordinance to change the name of McShane Place to Joseph Guillaume Place. The ordinance aims to rename the entire stretch of McShane Place, connecting North Rampart Street at St. Bernard Avenue to St. Claude Avenue. The electronic submission deadline was April 15, 2022.
- Ordinance Number: 33,577
- Votes Summary:

- Topic: Amendments to Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance for Billboard Study
- Summary: Councilmember Banks introduced an ordinance to amend and reordain Articles 24 and 25 of the Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance to incorporate certain recommendations and initiatives contained in the 2019 Billboard Study. The amendments include provisions for the conversion of billboards to digital format, conversion of billboards with two sides/faces, and protection against concentration of digitized billboards in specific areas of the city.
- Ordinance Number: 33,578
- Votes Summary:

- Topic: Waiver of Fees for Toy Giveaway Event at Tremé Community Center
- Summary: The ordinance aims to temporarily waive certain fees, permit fees, and requirements for an event at the Tremé Community Center. The event is a toy giveaway organized by the Mystic Krewe of Femme Fatale and Colorful Butterfly Foundation. The waiver is specified for the event scheduled on December 18, 2021, from 9:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m.
- Ordinance Number: 33579
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (8 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 1 ABSENT)

- Topic: Establishment of Protect Tremé Interim Zoning District
- Summary: This ordinance seeks to amend and establish a new Interim Zoning District (IZD) named the Protect Tremé Interim Zoning District. The intent is to prohibit certain uses in the Tremé neighborhood to safeguard its historic structures and culture until a comprehensive vision for the future of Tremé is developed.
- Ordinance Number: 33580
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (5 YEAS, 3 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 1 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed, establishing the Protect Tremé Interim Zoning District to safeguard the historic structures and culture of the Tremé neighborhood.
- Tags/Keywords: Zoning District, Tremé Neighborhood, Historic Preservation
- UID: 3b9b543f-4796-4815-97c6-856709c087de

It also prohibits NOPD leadership from authorizing deviation from any NOPD policy. The ordinance was continued to the meeting of 9/2/21.

- Summary: The ordinance aims to modify the Neighborhood Participation Program (NPP) requirements to allow teleconferencing, virtual, or other remote meeting formats to satisfy NPP requirements during a declared emergency by the Governor or Mayor, when in-person meetings are not an available option.
- Ordinance Number: CAL. NO. 33,416
- Votes Summary:
  Vote 1: Passed - (Unanimous)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed without any amendments.
- Tags/Keywords: Neighborhood Participation Program, remote meeting formats, declared emergencies
- UID: 7b81bac3-fab7-41f1-8a58-0791bb670955

- Ordinance Number: CAL. NO. 33,417
- Votes Summary:
  Vote 1: Passed - (6 YEAS, 1 NAY)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed with a majority vote, with one council member voting against it.
- Tags/Keywords: Child care centers, residential districts, zoning ordinance
- UID: 7b81bac3-fab7-41f1-8a58-0791bb670955

- Topic: Designated truck routes in the City of New Orleans
- Summary: This ordinance aims to amend and reordain Section 154-1561 of the Code of the City of New Orleans, relative to designated truck routes, specifically removing Felicity Street as a truck route and adding Martin Luther King Jr Blvd as a truck route.
- Ordinance Number: CAL. NO. 33,418
- Votes Summary:
  Vote 1: Passed - (Unanimous)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed without any amendments.
- Tags/Keywords: Truck routes, transportation ordinance, designated routes

- Topic: Amendment to City's Smoke Free Air Act
- Summary: The ordinance aimed to amend and reordain sections of the City's Smoke Free Air Act to authorize NOPD to enforce the act only via summons and to prohibit the smoking of marijuana outside of a private residence.
- Ordinance Number: CAL. NO. 33,329
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 0 ABSENT)
    Vote 2: Amendment No. 1 - Passed
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance was passed with an amendment to clarify that police officers issuing a municipal summons are not required to seize or take possession of any product or object being smoked in violation of the Smoke Free Air Act.
- Tags/Keywords: Smoke Free Air Act, NOPD, marijuana smoking
- UID: 0d68f700-c114-4914-8e4d-8c84dc0b6bcd

- Topic: Amendment of Comprehensive Zoning Code
- Summary: The ordinance proposes to eliminate or modify the height limit increase in the Riverfront Overlay RIV-2 Algiers Sub-District Standards, with the intent of allowing only the minimum height bonus necessary to achieve a view of the river from the upper story of a three-floor development. It also considers adding a possible parking bonus as an affordable housing incentive within specific boundaries.
- Ordinance Number: ZD NO. 3/21
- Votes Summary:
  Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 2 ABSTAIN, 1 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The motion approving the favorable recommendation of the City Planning Commission of Zoning Docket No. 3/21 was passed with additional modification to the height limitations.

- Topic: Granting a Non-Exclusive Franchise to McLeodUSA Telecommunications Services, LLC
- Summary: The ordinance grants a non-exclusive franchise to McLeodUSA Telecommunications Services, LLC, to construct and operate a fiber-optic based communications system. The ordinance was continued to the meeting of 6/3/21.
- Ordinance Number: 32930
- Votes Summary:

- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance was continued to the next meeting for further discussion and consideration.
- UID: 2c2b44d3-be73-47df-a5ba-adb757f78a19

- Topic: Amending Police Code Sections for Access to Camera Footage
- Summary: The ordinance aims to mandate prompt access to body-worn and in-car camera footage for arrestees or their legal counsel. It also prohibits deviations from NOPD policy and entering into agreements exempting law enforcement officers from NOPD policy. An amendment was proposed to create exceptions for footage that could compromise an investigation pending court authorization and to remove the provision prohibiting NOPD from entering into agreements regarding exceptions to NOPD policy. The ordinance was continued to the meeting of 6/3/21.
- Ordinance Number: 33018
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Continued to the meeting of 6/3/21
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance and its proposed amendment were continued to the next meeting for further discussion and consideration.
- UID: 2c2b44d3-be73-47df-a5ba-adb757f78a19

- Topic: Amendments to ordinance related to police body-worn and in-car camera footage
- Summary: The amendments create an exception from the 30-day production requirement for footage that would compromise an investigation or endanger witnesses, pending Court authorization. messages.page_content:
- Topic: Granting of Servitude Agreement for Tchoupitoulas Street
- Summary: The ordinance authorized the Mayor to enter into an agreement to grant a servitude consisting of air and ground rights not needed for public purposes to an adjacent property owner for encroachments on/over portions of the public right-of-way adjacent to 3969 Tchoupitoulas Street. The ordinance was submitted by Councilmember Banks and was electronically submitted for postponement on 9/17/21.
- Ordinance Number: 33339
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 0 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed without amendments.
- Tags/Keywords: Servitude Agreement, Tchoupitoulas Street, Councilmember Banks
- UID: c8fa0807-74b0-4e19-8e4c-60faa5dedd3e

- Topic: Lease with New Cingular Wireless PCS, LLC for Rooftop Space
- Summary: This ordinance authorized the Mayor to execute a lease with New Cingular Wireless PCS, LLC for a portion of the rooftop space located at 1601 Perdido Street for a period of five years, with optional renewal terms. The yearly rental was set at $30,000.00 with a fifteen percent increase for each renewal term. 
- Ordinance Number: 33340
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 0 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed without amendments.
- Tags/Keywords: Lease, New Cingular Wireless, Perdido Street
- UID: c8fa0807-74b0-4e19-8e4c-60faa5dedd3e

- Topic: Lease with United States Postal Service for Property on Liberty Street
- Summary: This ordinance authorized the Mayor to execute a lease with the United States Postal Service for property consisting of portions of South Liberty Street and Julia Street in the First Municipal District of New Orleans. The lease was for a period from October 1, 2020, to September 30, 2025, with a yearly rental of $259,022.00 and a flat increase to a total rent of $293,060.00 per year for one five-year option term.
- Ordinance Number: 33341
- Votes Summary:
    Vote 1: Passed - (7 YEAS, 0 NAYS, 0 ABSTAIN, 0 ABSENT)
- Decision/Key Actions: The ordinance passed without amendments.
- Tags/Keywords: Lease, United States Postal Service, Liberty Street
- UID: c8fa0807-74b0-4e19-8e4c-60faa5dedd3e
